Effect of calcination temperature on the structure and performance of rod-like MnCeOx derived from MOFs catalysts Xiaodong Zhang Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ Shang Xiang Writing – original draft a Quanxin Du Data curation a Fukun Bi Formal analysis a Kailin Xie Visualization a Lu Wang Writing – review & editing b ⁎ a School of Environment and Architecture, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China School of Environment and Architecture University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai 200093 China aSchool of Environment and Architecture, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China b Public Experiment Center, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China Public Experiment Center University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai 200093 China bPublic Experiment Center, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In our work, metal organic framework (MOFs)-derived MnCeOx catalysts were synthesized by different calcination temperatures. Effect of calcination temperature was characterized by thermogravimetric (TG), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature programmed H2 reduction (H2-TPR). Performance testing of toluene found that 1Mn1Ce-300 showed the best performance (T90 = 244 °C), good durability and reliable water resistance in catalyzing toluene. The better catalytic performance of 1Mn1Ce-300 was attributed to the higher molar ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+, Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt, more adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy and better low-temperature reduction. In situ diffuse reflectance, infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) and thermal desorption-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (TD-GC-MS) proved that benzoic acid and benzene were the main intermediates. This work was instructive for the preparation of metal oxide catalysts by pyrolysis of MOFs. Graphical abstract Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords MOFs derivative Toluene oxidation MnCeOx Calcination temperature 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as aromatic hydrocarbons, aromatic hydrocarbons, aldehydes and haloalkanes were precursors to cause many air pollution events such as photochemical smog and haze [1,2]. Therefore, the removal of VOCs before emission into the atmosphere was an important and urgent task. Current technologies for removing VOCs could be divided into physical and chemical methods, which included adsorption [3], catalytic oxidation [4] and photocatalysis [5]. Among them, catalytic oxidation had the advantages of low cost, high efficiency and environmental friendliness [4,6,7]. The focus of improving the efficiency of catalytic oxidation was to investigate efficient and stable catalysts, which were generally used as transition metal catalysts (Mn, Co, Fe and Ni) [8–10] and precious metal catalysts (Ag, Pt and Pd) [11–13]. Although noble metal catalysts generally possessed higher catalytic efficiency, their expensive price limited their application and development. Compared with noble metal catalysts, transition metal catalysts were cheaper and more thermally stable. To control the emission of VOCs, More efficient and stable transition metal catalysts should be researched [14,15]. The preparation methods of transition metal catalysts could be divided into two categories, one of which was the one-step synthesis of transition metal catalysts [16,17], and the other was two-step synthesis of transition metal oxides by sacrificial template method [18–20]. Recently, MOFs materials had been widely used in the fields of adsorption [21], advanced oxidation [22,23], photocatalysis [24] and catalytic oxidation [25] due to high specific surface areas, easy surface functionalization and adjustable pore size. Specifically, in catalytic oxidation, the sacrificial template method using MOFs as precursors was considered effective [26]. Among these transition metals, Mn elements were considered as suitable transition metal catalysts because of the variable valence state, low cost and high activity in the catalysis of VOCs [27]. In our previous research [10], The Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst by pyrolyzing the MOF precursor of Mn-MIL-100 with Ar-O2 atmosphere showed higher catalytic activity for toluene. Additionally, Ce was a rare earth metal with excellent redox ability, easy formation of oxygen vacancies and high oxygen storage capacity [26,28]. Sun et al [29]. reported in three different MOF precursors, Ce-BTC, Ce-MOF-808 and Ce-UiO-66. The CeO2-MOF-808 derivative catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance (T90 = 278 °C) because of its larger specific surface area, more active oxygen and better low-temperature reducibility. Moreover, the catalyst performance was further improved in order to combine the advantages of Mn and Ce [30,31]. Chen et al [32]. prepared the binary oxide of 3Mn1Ce synthesized by hydrolysis driving redox method, due to the introduction of Ce, besides the excellent catalytic effect (T90 = 210 °C), the catalyst had good structural stability for catalysis and reversible reduction of VOCs. In addition, Liu et al [33]. found that the calcination of 3DOM MnCeO3 at 600 °C had better-adsorbed oxygen concentration, lower reduction temperature and more large specific surface area. In previous studies, the Mn-Ce catalysts showed better catalytic performance compared with Mn-based or Ce-based catalysts alone. However, the effect of calcination temperature on the performance and physicochemical properties of Mn-Ce catalysts during the process of obtaining transition metal catalysts by pyrolysis of MOF had not been considered. Therefore, MnCeOx catalysts were synthesized with different calcination temperatures in this work. A series of characterization results (TG, XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, XPS and H2-TPR) proved that the calcination temperature of pyrolyzing MOF precursor affected the chemical state of the catalyst surface metal, adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy concentration and low-temperature reduction ability. The different calcination temperatures on the catalytic activity of toluene were researched in detail. In addition, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV), cyclability, stability and water resistance were measured. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS and TD-GC-MS were used to study the intermediate products of toluene degradation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were analytical reagents and could be used directly without further purification. Manganese(Ⅱ) nitrate tetrahydrate (Mn (NO3)2·4H2O, 98.0%), 1, 3, 5-phthalic acid (H3-BTC, 98%), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5%), Cerous (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce (NO3)3·6H2O, 99.0%), and absolute ethanol (99.7%) were procured from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of 1Mn1Ce-BTC According to our previous work [31]. 1Mn1Ce-BTC was synthesized through the hydrothermal method. Typically, 0.65 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3-BTC), 0.50 g of Mn (NO3)2·4H2O and 0.58 g of Ce (NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 60 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF). Stirring the mixture until it was completely dissolved, then it was moved to a 150 ml PTFE-lined reactor, and finally, the reactor was placed in an oven, and the program was set to react at 120 °C for 24 h. After the solution was cooled to room temperature, the solution was washed with absolute ethanol by centrifugation three times. Finally, the washed 1Mn1Ce-BTC white precipitate was placed in an oven at 80 °C and dried overnight. 2.2.2 Preparation of 1Mn1Ce-BTC derived 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts with different calcination temperatures Our previous study [10] indicated that the sample pretreated under O2 after Ar atmosphere (Ar-O2 treatment) was beneficial to improve catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. During the pretreatment of Ar, the structure of the samples could be maintained. The sample with a bigger surface area could be obtained in the further treatment under O2 atmosphere. Therefore, all samples are prepared by Ar-O2 treatment. 1Mn1Ce-BTC was first calcined at 200 °C under Ar atmosphere for 2 h, and then at 200 °C under O2 atmosphere for 2 h. The black powder was obtained and named as 1Mn1Ce-200, and finally, the other products obtained by calcination at 300 °C, 400 °C and 500 °C were marked as 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400 and 1Mn1Ce-500, respectively. 2.2.3 Synthesis of CeO2 and Mn3O4 For comparison, the Mn3O4 and CeO2 were prepared by pyrolyzing Mn-BTC and Ce-BTC. Mn-BTC [9] and Ce-BTC [34] were prepared by solvothermal method according to our previous works. Generally, for Mn-BTC, 0.39 g of H3-BTC was dissolved in 18 ml of methanol under constant stirring at 35 °C. After the complete dissolution of H3-BTC, 0.5 g of Mn (NO3)2·4H2O was added to the above solution. And kept under stirring until it was clear. Then the mixture was transferred to the autoclave, reacted at 120 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, the brown powder could be obtained by centrifugation, washing with ethanol three times and drying at 80 °C in an oven overnight. And for Ce-BTC, 0.63 g of H3BTC and 2.17 g of Ce (NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 50 ml of DMF. Then, the mixture was sealed in a 100 ml Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave and heated to 130 °C for 24 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the product was filtered, washed by centrifugation with DMF and ethanol for three times, and dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h to prepare Ce-BTC materials. Mn-BTC and Ce-BTC were first calcined at 300 °C under Ar atmosphere for 2 h, and then at 300 °C under O2 atmosphere for 2 h. The black powder was obtained and named as Mn3O4 and CeO2. 2.3 Characterization The physical and chemical parameters and morphology of the catalysts were tested by the following characterization methods. Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were obtained on a synchronous thermal analyzer (PerkinElmer, STA8000) at the heating rate of 10 °C/min in air atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were detected on a Bruker D8 Advance. X-ray diffractometer using a monochromatic Cu Kα radiation detector (40 kV, 40 mA) with a scan speed of 5°/min, scan range 10°∼80°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and highresolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were obtained by FEI Talos F200S Super-X energy dispersive spectroscopy. The pore properties of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77 K (liquid nitrogen temperature) on a quantachrome autosorb-iQ-2MP apparatus. Before analysis, samples were degassed under vacuum at 105 °C for 12 h until purification. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model was used to calculate the specific surface area, and the pore size distributions were generated by density functional theory (DFT). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on THERMO ESCALAB 250XZ. The binding energies were calibrated internally by C1s carbon deposition at 284.8 eV. Temperature-programmed H2 reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a ChemBET TPR/TPD chemisorption analyzer. For H2-TPR, prior to testing, the samples were pretreated under N2 atmosphere at 150 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the gas was changed to 5.0 vol. % H2/Ar, and the programmed temperature reduction started from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. In situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) was performed on Nicolet iS50 (Thermo Fisher, America) equipped with a Harrick in-situ cell was used to explore the mechanism of catalytic combustion of toluene. Approximately 50 mg of catalyst was added to the wedge of the diffuse reflection cell. The sample was first pretreated under Ar atmosphere at 300 °C for 2 h, and then the sample was cooled to room temperature. The gas was changed to Ar or 20 vol. % O2/Ar, and DEGRADATIONS of the as-pretreated sample were taken as background. Then, toluene gas was introduced by Ar or 20% O2/Ar for 1 h. Finally, the sample temperature reached the target temperature and the signal was collected. Thermal desorption-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (TD-GC-MS) was used to analyze the gas-phase organic compounds during the toluene degradation process. The output by-products are first collected through the Tenax-TA tube and the captured gas is then released into a thermal desorption apparatus equipped with a GC-MS analyzer. Desorption condition: the Tenax-TA tube was desorbed at 280 °C for 10 min. And the desorbed gas was enriched in the collector at 5 °C. Then, the manifold was rapidly heated to 300 °C at a rate of 40 °C/min and held for 6 min. Finally, the gas was introduced into the GC-MS for detection. GC-MS test condition: column box temperature 40 °C, ion source temperature 230 °C, four-stage rod temperature 150 °C. Heating schedule: the initial temperature was 40 °C, held 5 min, then increased to 180 °C at 5 °C/min, held 5 min. 2.4 Catalysts test The catalytic oxidation performance of toluene was tested in a flowing fixed bed reactor under normal pressure. 0.1 g (20-40 mesh) catalyst was sealed in a quartz tube reactor (outer diameter 6 mm). Toluene was injected by a syringe at a suitable constant speed in order to keep the toluene concentration of 1000 ppm. The rate of gas flow was 50 mL/min (20 vol. % O2 +80 vol. % Ar) and could be adjusted by the flow meter. Additionally, in order to research the influence of H2O on the toluene-catalyzed reaction, gases with different content of H2O (5.0 and 10.0 vol. %) were realized by a water saturator. The VOCs concentration of outlet and inlet were detected by on-line gas chromatograph (GC) loaded with a flame ionization (FID) detector. The temperatures of toluene conversion rate at 90 % and 50 % (T90 and T50) were two indicators, which evaluated the activation activity of the catalyst. The toluene conversion (Xtoluene ) was counted according to the following formula: (1) X t o l u e n e ( % ) = C i n l e t − C o u t l e t C i n l e t × 100 % Where C outlet and C inlet were the concentration of toluene in outlet and inlet gas, respectively. The activation energies of oxidation reaction (Ea , kJ/mol) were also counted based on the Arrhenius equation, in the case of X toluene lower than 20%: (2) r = − k c = [ − A exp ( − E a / R T ) ] c Where k, A, Ea and r were for rate constant (s−1), pre-exponential factor, apparent activation energy (kJ/mol) and reaction rate (μmol/(g·s)), respectively. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Fig. 1 showed the XRD patterns of 1Mn1Ce-BTC, 1Mn1Ce-200, 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400 and 1Mn1Ce-500 catalysts. The XRD pattern of 1Mn1Ce-BTC was consistent with previous research [35], which indicated the successful synthesis of MOFs. After calcination at different temperatures, the characteristic peaks of 1Mn1Ce-BTC were not observed in these calcined samples due to the collapse of the skeleton of 1Mn1Ce-BTC. In addition, all the samples showed the characteristic peaks of manganese oxide and cerium dioxide. The peaks at 31.0°, 32.3°, 36.1°, 38.0° and 58.5° corresponded to (200), (103), (211), (004) and (321) crystal planes of Mn3O4 (PDF #24−0734), respectively. The diffraction peaks at 59.1°, 56.3°, 47.4°, 33.1° and 28.5° corresponded to the (222), (311), (220), (200) and (111) crystal planes of CeO2 (PDF #34 -0394), respectively. Noteworthy, as the calcination temperature increased, the peaks of Mn3O4 and CeO2 both increased first and then decreased. This was because the calcination temperature changed the phase composition of 1Mn1Ce oxides. Moreover, in order to compare the performance difference between composite 1Mn1Ce oxide and individual Mn oxide and Ce oxide catalysts. Fig. S1 showed the XRD pattern of Ce-BTC, Mn-BTC, CeO2 and Mn3O4, which was consistent with the previous study and proved their successful synthesis [9,34]. Fig. 2 showed SEM images of 1Mn1Ce-200 (a), 1Mn1Ce-300 (b), 1Mn1Ce-400 (c) and 1Mn1Ce-500 (d) catalysts. The 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures basically maintain the rod shape. Especially, the grain size of 1Mn1Ce-200 was 4 μm, which was much larger than that of 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400 and 1Mn1Ce-500. This was because the organic ligand (H3-BTC) was not completely removed due to the low calcination temperature of 1Mn1Ce-200. In summary, the 1Mn1Ce-BTC template could form 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts with rod-like morphology after heat treatment. TEM and HR-TEM pictures of 1Mn1Ce-300 were displayed in Fig. 2(e, f). The 1Mn1Ce-300 was a rod-like structure (Fig. 2(e)). Besides, Fig. 2(f) showed two lattice spacings of 0.292 nm and 0.316 nm, which corresponded to the crystallographic faces of CeO2 (111) and Mn3O4 (103), respectively. This was consistent with the XRD results. Fig. 3 showed the N2 adsorption-desorption curves and pore size distribution of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3(a), all catalysts had H3-type hysteresis loops with type IV isotherms, which showed that all catalysts had a mesoporous structure [34,35]. And the specific surface areas of 1Mn1Ce-200, 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400 and 1Mn1Ce-500 were 107.4 m2/g, 171.2 m2/g, 181.3 m2/g and 196.5 m2/g, respectively. With the calcination temperature rising, the specific surface area of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts became larger. However, as the calcination temperature increased, the interaction between manganese and cerium increased, which caused the pore volume of the 1Mn1Ce oxide catalyst to decrease, and when the temperature rose to 500 °C, the interaction between manganese and cerium weakened, which led to an increase in the pore volume of the 1Mn1Ce oxide catalyst. The XPS of samples were applied to quantitatively describe the surface chemical state of these catalysts. Ce 3d, Mn 2p, and O 1s XPS spectra of these catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 4 . The Mn 2p XPS spectra were exhibited in Fig. 4(a). The binding energies of Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 were located at 653.3 and 641.7 eV, respectively. Then for Mn 2p3/2, the peaks of 640.8, 641.7, 642.7 and 646.5 eV were considered to Mn2+, Mn3+, Mn4+ and satellite, respectively [36]. The satellite excitation was typical for Mn2+ [37] Table 1. showed the molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ calculated from the peak area. And the ratio of Mn3+ to Mn4+ followed the order: 1Mn1Ce-300 (1.09) > 1Mn1Ce-400 (0.85) > 1Mn1Ce-500 (0.81) > 1Mn1Ce-200 (0.69). The massive presence of Mn3+ on the surface of 1Mn1Ce-300 promoted the adsorption and activation of oxygen [38,39]. Fig 4(b) exhibited the Ce 3d of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts included eight peaks at 916.8, 907.8, 903.8, 901.1, 898.4, 889.1, 886.4 and 882.6 eV corresponding to U’’’, U’’, U’, U, V’’’, V’’, V’ and V, respectively. The V and U implied the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Ce, respectively. The two peaks marked as U’ and V’ were considered to Ce3+ and the other six peaks named as U’’’, U’’, U’’, V’’’, V’’ and V were descried to Ce4+, which indicated that there are two valence states of Ce3+ and Ce4+ on the catalyst surface [26,40]. The appearance of Ce3+ indicated the appearance of oxygen vacancies in 1Mn1Ce oxides and that lattice oxygen could be stored and migrated between Ce4+ and Ce3+ [41,42]. The ratio of Ce3+ to Ce4+ followed the order (Table 1): 1Mn1Ce-300 (0.16) > 1Mn1Ce-400 (0.11) > 1Mn1Ce-500 (0.10) > 1Mn1Ce-200 (0.07), which proved that 1Mn1Ce-300 had the highest ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+. The large presence of Ce3+ on the surface of 1Mn1Ce-300 might bring about a charge imbalance, which resulted in the unsaturated chemical bonds and formation of oxygen vacancies on the 1Mn1Ce-300 surface [43]. For O 1s, Fig. 4(c) showed that peaks at 531.3-531.5 eV and 529.5-529.8 eV could be considered to the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olatt), respectively [35]. As the temperature increased, the characteristic peaks of 1Mn1Ce catalyst shifted to the direction of high binding energy, which might be due to the enhanced interaction between oxygen and manganese or cerium, resulting in the facilitated electron-transfer from oxygen to manganese or cerium [32,44]. When the temperature was 500 °C, the characteristic peaks shifted to the direction of low binding energy, which might be due to the weakened interaction between oxygen and manganese or cerium resulting in the inhibition of electron-transfer oxygen to manganese or cerium. The ratio of Oads to Olatt followed the order (Table 1): 1Mn1Ce-300 (1.28) > 1Mn1Ce-400 (0.68) > 1Mn1Ce-500 (0.46) > 1Mn1Ce-200 (0.40), which revealed that 1Mn1Ce-300 was provided with the highest rate of Oads to Olatt. Recent studies had found that the content of Oads was closely related to the number of the generation of surface oxygen vacancies and active oxygen molecules [45,46]. The highest Oads/Olatt molar ratio indicated the largest number of active oxygen species and oxygen vacancies [47]. H2-TPR (Fig. 5 ) showed the reduction behavior of various 1Mn1Ce oxide, Mn3O4, and CeO2 catalysts. As for Mn3O4, the H2 consumption peak appears at 531 °C could be the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [10,46]. In the case of CeO2, two H2 consumption peaks appearing at 555 and 482 °C could be considered as the reduction of lattice oxygen and Ce4+ to Ce3+, respectively [32]. In addition, three H2 consumption peaks were founded for 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts. The reduction peaks in the range of 200-300 °C were considered to reduce Mn2O3→Mn3O4 and the high temperature peak (300−450 °C) was denoted as reduction Mn3O4→MnO [48,49]. Additionally, the reduction peak within 450−600 °C was due to the reduction of CeO2. To quantitatively research the reduction of these four 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts, the consumption of total H2 consumption was counted and the results were shown in Table 1. The sequence of low temperature reduction follows: 1Mn1Ce-300 > 1Mn1Ce-400 > 1Mn1Ce-500 > 1Mn1Ce-200, which showed that 1Mn1Ce-300 catalyst had better reducibility. 3.2 Catalytic performance Toluene was used as a target contaminant to compare the catalytic effect of catalysts Fig. 6.(a) displayed the change curve of toluene conversion rate with temperature. Besides, the T10, T50 and T90 of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts obtained by different calcination temperatures were shown in Table 2 . The T90 of 1Mn1Ce-200, 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400, 1Mn1Ce-500, Mn3O4 and CeO2 were 283, 244, 264, 298, 266 and 286 °C, respectively. Among them, 1Mn1Ce-300 exhibited optimal catalytic performance. Additionally, compared with other MnCeOx oxide catalysts in other reports [28,32,44,50–53], the 1Mn1Ce-300 showed the best catalytic performance. The Ea of Mn3O4, CeO2 and the 1Mn1Ce oxides catalysts obtained by different calcination temperatures were counted based on Arrhenius formula. The Arrhenius plots were exhibited in Fig. 6(b) and the Ea of the catalysts were listed in Table 2. The Ea of 1Mn1Ce-200, 1Mn1Ce-300, 1Mn1Ce-400, 1Mn1Ce-500, Mn3O4 and CeO2 were 188.5, 73.6, 158.7 213.5, 159.0 and 188.3 kJ/mol. Among these catalysts, the Ea of 1Mn1Ce-300 was the smallest, which indicated that 1Mn1Ce-300 was more likely to catalyze the degradation of toluene. Fig. S2 displayed the TG curves of Mn1Ce-BTC and 1Mn1Ce-300 oxide. When the temperature rose to 300 °C, The structure of 1Mn1Ce-BTC began to collapse. Moreover, in order to investigate whether the complete decomposition of organic ligands during calcination. The TG curve of 1Mn1Ce-300 oxide did not change under air atmosphere, which proved the structure of 1Mn1Ce-BTC has completely collapsed. 1Mn-Ce-300 was selected to research the influence of reusability, stability and WSHV of the catalysts and water resistance Fig. 7.(a-c) displayed the influence of WSHV, reusability and stability. High WSHV would affect the catalytic performance of 1Mn-Ce-300, The catalytic performance of toluene decreased as WSHV increased. And 1Mn-Ce-300 exhibited good stability and reusability. Furthermore, to prove the good reusability and stability, the crystal structure of 1Mn-1Ce-300 after toluene oxidation was measured by XRD. After the catalytic toluene reaction, the pattern of the 1Mn-Ce-300 did not change in Fig. S3, which indicated a good stability of the 1Mn-Ce-300. Fig. 7.(d) presented the effect of 5.0 vol. % and 10.0 vol. % H2O at 225 °C for toluene over 1Mn-Ce-300. It could be found that the addition of H2O slightly improved the conversion rate of toluene, indicating good water resistance of the 1Mn-Ce-300. 3.3 The effect of calcination temperature For these four 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts calcined at different temperatures. XRD (Fig. 1) showed that the peak intensities of both Mn3O4 and CeO2 decreased and then increased as the calcination temperature increased, which indicated that the calcination temperature affected the crystal composition of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts. SEM (Fig. 2) exhibited the calcination temperature affected its morphology, at lower calcination temperatures, incomplete removal of organic ligands led to unclear rod structure, and 1Mn1Ce-300 calcination at 300 °C had a distinct rod-like structure. In addition, the rise in calcination temperature increased the specific surface area of 1Mn1Ce oxide catalysts, then as the calcination temperature increased, the pore volume first became smaller and then increased (Table 1). This result indicated the catalytic activity of toluene was not obviously affected by the specific surface area and pore size dispersion of the catalysts. Besides, surface chemical composition, adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy concentration and low-temperature reduction capacity had a significant impact on the catalytic performance of MnCeOx oxide catalysts [31]. Based on the analysis of the above catalytic properties and related characterization results, it could be found that the catalysts obtained from different calcination temperatures had different catalyst composition, morphology, surface area, pore size distribution chemical states of surface metals, adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy concentration and low temperature reduction capacity, which further affected their catalytic activity. Better low temperature reduction capacity, more adsorbed oxygen species and oxygen vacancies could promote the degradation of toluene [54]. The datum of O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 4(c) and Table 1) showed 1Mn-Ce-300 had the most molar ratio of Oads/Olatt (1.28). More adsorbed oxygen proved that there were more surface oxygen vacancies, which would enhance the catalytic performance of the catalyst to toluene [55]. Furthermore, the presence of more oxygen vacancies was also evidenced by a larger molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Mn3+/Mn4+. From Fig. 4(a, b) and Table 1, it could be found that the 1Mn-Ce-300 had the largest molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ (1.09) and Ce3+/Ce4+ (0.16). This indicated the presence of more oxygen vacancies in 1Mn-Ce-300, which further indicated that 1Mn-Ce-300 had a better catalytic performance for toluene. In addition, the 1Mn-Ce-300 possessed a better low-temperature reduction ability, which was proved by the H2-TPR datum (Fig. 5 and Table 1). In summary, the better catalytic performance of 1Mn-Ce-300 could be attributed to the high molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+, Oads/Olatt, and Mn3+/Mn4+, more adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy and better low-temperature reduction. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism In situ DRIFTS was used to analyze the intermediate product of toluene on 1Mn-Ce-300. The lattice oxygen was mainly involved in the catalytic oxidation reaction according to the Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism. Therefore, the role of the lattice oxygen was studied Fig. 8.(a) showed the intermediate products on the surface of the 1Mn-Ce-300 as the temperature increased under Ar atmosphere. The absorption bond at 1180 cm−1 was considered to types of alcohol (C-O stretching vibration) [56,57]. The absorption bonds at 1510, 1391 cm−1 might suggest types of carboxylates (the stretching vibration of CO bond stretching vibration) [58,59]; the absorption bands at 1226 cm−1 were due to the existence of maleic anhydrides species [57,60]; the peak at 2376 and 2308 cm−1 might represent CO2 [61]. The change of intermediate products at different temperatures was shown by color change Fig. 8(b) Fig. 8.(b) showed that toluene was mineralized to CO2 in Ar atmosphere with increasing temperature, but intermediate products such as benzoic acid were not fully converted to the next intermediate product even at 300 °C. To sum up, without the supplementation of gaseous oxygen, mineralization of toluene by lattice oxygen of the oxide itself alone was inefficient. Compared with Fig. 8(a, b), as shown in Fig. 8(c, d), under O2 atmosphere, as the temperature increased, intermediates such as benzoic acid could be completely converted to the next intermediate at 300 °C, while toluene was mineralized to more CO2. Therefore, according to the result of in situ DRIFTS spectra, gaseous oxygen could accelerate the formation and conversion of intermediates by supplementing lattice oxygen, which compounded Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism of catalytic oxidation for toluene. TD-GC-MS was used to study the intermediate products in the degradation process of toluene Fig. 9. showed the intermediate product of 1Mn1Ce-BTC in the process of catalyzing toluene. Four substances were detected. According to in situ DRIFTS results, lattice oxygen supplemented by gaseous oxygen could better oxidize toluene. At 150 °C, (1) O2 was detected, indicating that the lattice oxygen did not require all gaseous oxygen to supplement at 150 °C. The production of (2) benzene and (4) O-xylene were due to the disproportionation reaction of toluene. Toluene removed a methyl group to form (2) benzene, and toluene added a methyl group to form (4) O-xylene. When the temperature rose to 260 °C, the (2) toluene was almost completely degraded. According to the results of in situ DRIFTS and GC-MS. The degradation pathway of toluene was shown in Fig. 10 . A small part of toluene was disproportionated into benzene and o-xylene. According to the report [62,63], benzene was further oxidized to phenol, benzoquinone and then to maleic acid. The o-xylene was further oxidized to phthalic acid. The intermediate products were eventually turned into CO2 and H2O. Most of toluene was first oxidized to benzyl alcohol, then to benzaldehyde, and finally to benzoic acid. The benzene ring was oxidized and opened to form intermediate products such as maleic acid, and finally oxidized to H2O and CO2. 4 Conclusion In summary, MnCeOx oxide catalysts were synthesized by different of calcination temperature. Surface chemical composition, adsorbed oxygen, oxygen vacancy concentration and low-temperature reduction capacity of MnCeOx catalysis were influenced by the calcination temperature according to a series of experimental and characterization results, which further influenced the catalytic effect for toluene. Among these MnCeOx catalysts calcination at different temperatures, the 1Mn1Ce-300 calcination at 300 °C exhibited the best performance in catalytic oxidation of toluene. High molar ratio of Oads/Olatt, Mn3+/Mn4+ and Ce3+/Ce4+, more adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy and better low-temperature reduction of 1Mn1Ce-300 were obtained by XPS and H2-TPR, which promoted the improvement of the catalytic effect of toluene. In addition, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV), cyclability, stability and water resistance showed 1Mn1Ce-300 had good durability and reliable water resistance. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS and TD-GC-MS demonstrated that 1Mn1Ce-300 could accelerate the mineralization of toluene by supplementing lattice oxygen with gaseous oxygen and that benzene and benzoic acid were the major intermediates. This work was instructive for the preparation of MOF-derived catalysts by calcination. coredata.dc:description: In our work, metal organic framework (MOFs)-derived MnCeOx catalysts were synthesized by different calcination temperatures. Effect of calcination temperature was characterized by thermogravimetric (TG), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature programmed H2 reduction (H2-TPR). Performance testing of toluene found that 1Mn1Ce-300 showed the best performance (T90 = 244 °C), good durability and reliable water resistance in catalyzing toluene. The better catalytic performance of 1Mn1Ce-300 was attributed to the higher molar ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+, Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt, more adsorbed oxygen, surface oxygen vacancy and better low-temperature reduction. In situ diffuse reflectance, infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) and thermal desorption-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (TD-GC-MS) proved that benzoic acid and benzene were the main intermediates. This work was instructive for the preparation of metal oxide catalysts by pyrolysis of MOFs.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of calcination temperature on the structure and performance of rod-like MnCeOx derived from MOFs catalysts
